item.title: üìñ Introduction
item.description: Most researchers write notes every day. This banality positions note-taking as practice requiring little explanation: We read something, attend a lecture, or make a research observation, and then commit it to paper (digital or otherwise), storing it for retrieval at a later date (or not).

item.title: üìñ Iteration
item.description: Review and re-evaluate notes periodically A note is not necessarily complete once it is written. Future information may come to shape a note slightly differently or encourage it to be merged with another note‚Äîor atomized (Node 1) into further notes.

item.title: üìñ Notes as constructions of knowledge
item.description: As a form of writing, note-taking is an inherently creative act, always involving thought rather than simply representing it ( Gibbs, 2007).

item.title: üìñ Notes as representations of knowledge
item.description: Most of the literature on note-taking focuses on writing individual notes on a particular topic, usually with an emphasis on their use as memory aids.

item.title: üìñ Notes as structures of knowledge
item.description: Whether understood as materializations of memory or the process of situated thought itself, notes do not stand alone: They are always in relation to other thoughts, ideas, and observations.

item.title: üìñ On format
item.description: The strength of a feminist note-taking system, as I will come to argue, is its networked qualities‚Äîa strength that is not necessarily shared with essays or linear arguements.

item.title: üìñ Principle of atomicity
item.description: Write notes to include only one idea Establishing a networked note-taking system requires reconceptualizing what makes up a note. Primarily, we are concerned here with notes which contain ideas: Notes on other types of information such as biographical data or shopping lists are not necessarily the most useful within the network (although biographical data can be usefully linked to particular ideas as a form of citation, as this digital paper strives to demonstrate).

item.title: üìñ Principle of flatness
item.description: Store notes in one container Whether working on a computer or on paper, typical file structures rely on folders and subfolders to organize information.

item.title: üìñ Principle of interconnection
item.description: Link notes liberally Refusing to rely on containers or long-winded details to organize and contextualize our notes means we must instead turn to the use of other notes to function in these capacities.

item.title: üìñ Principle of iteration
item.description: Review and re-evaluate notes periodically The last principle of a networked note-taking system is the principle of iteration. A note is not necessarily complete once it is written.
